title: Distributed Data Show Episode 1: Introduction to KillrVideo with Luke Tillman
description:
KillrVideo is a reference application for DataStax Enterprise.  This inaugural DataStax Academy Roundtable is a brief intro into what KillrVideo is, what it provides, and who might get something out of it.  

ABOUT DATASTAX ENTERPRISE 5
DataStax Enterprise 5.0, the database platform for cloud applications, includes Apache Cassandra 3.x with materialized views, tiered storage and advanced replication. Introduced in 5.0 is DataStax Enterprise Graph, the first graph database fast enough to power customer-facing applications, scale to massive datasets and integrate advanced tools to power deep analytical queries.

Learn more at http://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise and https://academy.datastax.com/resources/whats-new-datastax-enterprise-50

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX
Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastax?sub_confirmation=1 
Site: http://datastax.com 
Facebook: https://facebook.com/datastax 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastax 
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/datastax
http://feeds.feedburner.com/datastax 
https://github.com/datastax 

ABOUT DATASTAX ACADEMY
On the DataStax Academy YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, webinars and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on DataStax EnterpriseÂ©.  Create an account on https://academy.datastax.com to watch our free online courses, tutorials, and more.

from you know going from uh primarily.net shop to a.net and Java and Python and all of these other kind of Technologies so it's a problem people have in the real world as well so we needed some way to was actually the original way that you used to interact yeah that's right but it's also you know a kind of a way of doing RPC you know but uh you know if you're going to kind of offer micro microservice uh vrpc uh we could have done rest endpoints with HTTP and Json um we kind of ended up settling though on grpc which was this brand new framework it was in beta at the time when we were looking at it that let us use protocol buffers to Define our our contracts and then uh consume those or generate service code and whatnot in multiple programming languages so we have that um you know on the front end we had things like react and uh and uh an Express node.js backend because we wanted a reusable kind of uh web server that uh that could be reused by multiple you know microservice Summit and when we were on stage talking about killer video at that point killer video was a you know it was only available in c-sharp it was a.net application we had some um some kind of azure control [Laughter] that's funny you say that we did we did at one point have a problem with people going onto the live demo site like span spamming like borderline inappropriate working homes like yeah borderline inappropriate videos and we were like man what are we gonna do like do we have to actually put content like filters in place and wow that's like a whole other thing but really yeah programming languages what can we do uh you know to to have a Java version you know to have a node.js version things like that and so that's when we really made the move to okay let's you know we kind of got these service contracts already defined in the.net version let's let's go and look at some other pieces of Technology let's you know kind of make this not.net specific what what are some ways
